elements.content: The synthesis, structural characterization, luminescence properties, and proton conduction performance of a new family of isostructural cationic 2D layered compounds are reported. These have the general formula [Ln­(H4NMP)­(H2O)2]­Cl·2H2O [Ln = La3+, Pr3+, Sm3+, Eu3+, Gd3+, Tb3+, Dy3+, Ho3+, H6NMP = nitrilotris­(methylphosphonic acid)], and contain Cl– as the counterion. In the case of Ce3+, a 1D derivative, [Ce2(H3NMP)2(H2O)4]·4.5H2O, isostructural with the known lanthanum compound has been isolated by simply crystallization at room temperature. The octa-coordinated environment of Ln3+ in 2D compounds is composed by six oxygen atoms from three different ligands and two oxygens from each bound water. Two of the three phosphonate groups act as both chelating and bridging linkers, while the third phosphonate group acts solely as a bridging moiety. The materials are stable at low relative humidity at less at 170 °C. However, at high relative humidity transform to other chloride-free phases, including the 1D structure. The proton conductivity of the 1D materials varies in a wide range, the highest values corresponding to the La derivative (σ ≈ 2 × 10–3 S·cm–1 at RH 95% and 80 °C). A lower proton conductivity, 3 × 10–4 S·cm–1, was measured for [Gd­(H4NMP)­(H2O)2]­Cl·2H2O at 80 °C, which remains stable under the work conditions used. Absorption and luminescence spectra were recorded for selected [Ln­(H4NMP)­(H2O)2]­Cl·2H2O compounds. In all of them, the observed transitions are attributed solely to f–f transitions of the lanthanide ions present, as the H4NMP2– organic group has no measurable absorption or luminescence properties.

In the case of Ce3+, a 1D  derivative, [Ce2(H3NMP)2(H2O)4]⋅4.5H2O, isostructural with the known lanthanum compound has been isolated by simply crystallization at room temperature. The octa-coordinated environment of Ln3+ in 2D compounds is composed by six oxygen atoms from three different ligands and two oxygens from each bound water. Two of the three phosphonate groups act as both chelating and bridging linkers, while the third phosphonate group acts solely as a bridging moiety. The materials are stable at low relative humidity at less at 170 °C. However, at high relative humidity transform to other chloride-free phases, including the 1D structure. The proton conductivity of the 1D materials varies in a wide range, the highest values corresponding to the La derivative (σ ~ 2 × 10-3 S⋅cm-1 at RH 95% and 80 °C). A lower proton conductivity, 3 × 10-4 S⋅cm-1, was measured for [Gd(H4NMP)(H2O)2]Cl⋅2H2O at 80 °C, which remains stable under the work conditions used. Absorption and luminescence spectra were recorded for selected [Ln(H4NMP)(H2O)2]Cl⋅2H2O compounds. In all of them, the observed transitions are attributed solely to f-f transitions of the lanthanide ions present, as the H4NMP2- organic group has no measurable absorption or luminescence properties.

elements.content: A new family of isostructural 2D layered compounds, [Ln­(H4NMP)­(H2O)2]­Cl·2H2O [Ln = La3+, Pr3+, Sm3+, Eu3+, Gd3+, Tb3+, Dy3+, Ho3+] is reported. In these structures, positively charged sheets are electrostatically compensated with Cl− ions. Luminescence and proton conducting properties are described.

In these structures, positively charged sheets are electrostatically compensated with Cl- ions. Luminescence and proton conducting properties are described.

elements.content: Metal organic frameworks (MOFs) and coordination polymers are at the epicenter of interest of modern chemical and materials research and technology. A significant area in this field concerns metal-phosphonate frameworks. These are topologically composed of an inorganic part (a metal ion or metal cluster) and the phosphonate linker. The latter is commonly a polyphosphonic acid in its deprotonated form. Phosphonic acids are generally strong acids possessing two acidic protons, having the pKa1 < 1 and the pKa2 ≈ 7. Most reported metal phosphonates have been prepared in aqueous solutions at low pH. The reason for limiting the synthetic efforts in the low pH regime is the propensity of metal phosphonates to rapidly precipitate at “higher” pH values, thus yielding amorphous or poorly crystalline materials.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Metal organic frameworks (MOFs) and coordination polymers are at the epicenter of interest of modern chemical and materials research and technology. A significant area in this field concerns metal-phosphonate frameworks. These are topologically composed of an inorganic part (a metal ion or metal cluster) and the phosphonate linker. The latter is commonly a polyphosphonic acid in its deprotonated form. Phosphonic acids are generally strong acids possessing two acidic protons, having the pKa1 < 1 and the pKa2 ~ 7. Most reported metal phosphonates have been prepared in aqueous solutions at low pH. The reason for limiting the synthetic efforts in the low pH regime is the propensity of metal phosphonates to rapidly precipitate at "higher" pH values, thus yielding amorphous or poorly crystalline materials.

elements.content: In determining final properties of the solids, selection of the appropriate organic linker turns out a key factor not only because the metal–ligand connectivity determines the structural dimensionality but because it may contribute with specific functional groups. As a result, acidic groups usually remain in the structures upon crystallization, which are amenable to catalytic processes or promote hydrogen bond interactions with coordinated and/or lattice water molecules.
elements.clean_text: In determining final properties of the solids, selection of the appropriate organic linker turns out a key factor not only because the metal-ligand connectivity determines the structural dimensionality but because it may contribute with specific functional groups. As a result, acidic groups usually remain in the structures upon crystallization, which are amenable to catalytic processes or promote hydrogen bond interactions with coordinated and/or lattice water molecules.

elements.content: Nitrilotris­(methylphosphonic acid), H 6 NMP (the subscript number indicates the number of acidic protons), is a prototype ligand largely used in the preparation of crystalline M­(II)- and M­(III)-phosphonate materials. The reaction with M­(II) salts at a ligand-to-metal ratio 1:1 generated, in a quite predictable manner, isomorphic layered networks MII(H2O)3[HN­(CH2PO3H)3], the resulting 2D corrugated sheets being formed from complementary hydrogen-bonding interaction between 1D helical polymers. Therefore, in these organo-inorganic systems, hydrogen bonding, together with the presence of metal-coordinated water, most likely exerts the main control of the type of structure formed, irrespective of the metal ion employed.
elements.clean_text: Nitrilotris(methylphosphonic acid), H  6  NMP (the subscript number indicates the number of acidic protons), is a prototype ligand largely used in the preparation of crystalline M(II)- and M(III)-phosphonate materials. The reaction with M(II) salts at a ligand-to-metal ratio 1:1 generated, in a quite predictable manner, isomorphic layered networks MII(H2O)3[HN(CH2PO3H)3], the resulting 2D corrugated sheets being formed from complementary hydrogen-bonding interaction between 1D helical polymers. Therefore, in these organo-inorganic systems, hydrogen bonding, together with the presence of metal-coordinated water, most likely exerts the main control of the type of structure formed, irrespective of the metal ion employed.

elements.content: On the other hand, combining rare-earth cations with polyphosphonate linkers represents a unique opportunity of engineering optical centers into photoluminescent materials, designing catalysts and developing other interesting functionalities into well-defined crystalline compounds, such as proton conduction, etc. Apart from the choice of phosphonic acid, dimensionality may also be mediated by the choice of experimental conditions. Thus, 1D and 2D lanthanide-polyphosphonate networks have been reported for the system Ln-H6NMP. Soft synthesis conditions (1 min microwave irradiation, T = 60 °C), led to a 1D coordination polymer, composed of packed zigzag [La2(H3NMP)2(H2O)4] chains embedded into a matrix of highly disordered water molecules. This compound is chemically and thermally (up to 100 °C) stable, provided that coordinated water molecules remain attached to the metal centers. On the other hand, hydrothermal synthesis at T = 165 °C yielded a series of 2D compounds [Ln­(H3NMP)]·1.5H2O [Ln = La3+, Pr3+, Nd3+, Sm3+ and Eu3+] where the Ln3+ ions are exclusively coordinated to H3NMP3– anions in neutral undulated layers. Interlayer spaces are filled up with lattice water molecules, which are engaged in hydrogen-bonding interactions themselves and also with the POH groups. In addition, the material could be dehydrated at 200 °C without changing the structural features of the layers. Overall, the structural variations observed in lanthanide nitrilotris­(methylphosphonate) compounds show that small changes in metal–ligand connectivity can promote important changes in properties, and hence, it could be possible to exploit them for specific purposes.

elements.content: The strong H-bond networks exhibited by the Ln3+-nitrilotris­(methylphosphonates), together with their considerable thermal stability make them potential candidates for evaluation of their proton conduction properties. Because these H-bonding networks confer potential proton conduction capabilities in a wide range of temperature and relative humidity, studies of proton conducting metal phosphonates have been overwhelming during the last five years.

elements.content: This paper is part of our continuing efforts to design, synthesize, structurally characterize, and, finally, study the proton conduction properties of several metal phosphonates with diverse structural topologies. Herein, we describe the synthesis, structural characterization, luminescence properties, and proton conduction performance of a new family of cationic isostructural compounds, having the general formula [Ln­(H4NMP)­(H2O)2]­Cl·2H2O [Ln = La3+, Pr3+, Sm3+, Eu3+, Gd3+, Tb3+, Dy3+, Ho3+] and containing Cl– as the counterion. By way of comparison, we also report the proton conductivity of the 1D compounds [Ln2(H3NMP)2(H2O)4]·4.5H2O (Ln = La, Ce).

elements.content: Hydrated lanthanide nitrate or chloride reagents were purchased from Alfa-Aesar and used as received without further purification. Nitrilotris­(methylphosphonic acid) (H6NMP, 50% w/w solution in water as acid) was from ThermPhos, Switzerland. Stock solutions of HCl and NaOH were used for pH adjustments. In-house, deionized (DI) water was used for all syntheses.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials

Hydrated lanthanide nitrate or chloride reagents were purchased from Alfa-Aesar and used as received without further purification. Nitrilotris(methylphosphonic acid) (H6NMP, 50% w/w solution in water as acid) was from ThermPhos, Switzerland. Stock solutions of HCl and NaOH were used for pH adjustments. In-house, deionized (DI) water was used for all syntheses.

elements.content: Typically a mixture of H6NMP and the corresponding hydrated Ln3+ nitrate/chloride salt with a molar ratio 5:1 was prepared in water at room temperature as follows: 1.150 mmol (750 μL) of the 50% w/w H6NMP, stock solution were added in DI water (40 mL). The pH of the ligand solution was then adjusted to 0.6–0.8 by addition of HCl. Then 0.230 mmol of Ln3+ salt were gradually added under constant stirring. Synthesis of the lighter Ln3+, i.e. La3+ through Eu3+, derivatives usually required additional HCl to reach the high Cl–/Ln3+ molar ratios, in some case >9, necessary to incorporate Cl– into the structures. In all cases, the final pH of the mixed solution was adjusted to ∼0.6 with HCl. After several days, crystals of the final products appeared. The crystals were collected by filtration and dried in air. Typical yields were ∼70%. Further attempts to replace Cl– by other anions, such as SO4 2–, PO4 3–, and Br– in the same structure were unsuccessful.
elements.clean_text:
Syntheses of [Ln(H4NMP)(H2O)2]Cl⋅2H2O [Ln = La3+, Pr3+, Sm3+, Eu3+, Gd3+, Tb3+, Dy3+, Ho3+], Ln-H  4  NMPCl 

Typically a mixture of H6NMP and the corresponding hydrated Ln3+ nitrate/chloride salt with a molar ratio 5:1 was prepared in water at room temperature as follows: 1.150 mmol (750 μL) of the 50% w/w H6NMP, stock solution were added in DI water (40 mL). The pH of the ligand solution was then adjusted to 0.6-0.8 by addition of HCl. Then 0.230 mmol of Ln3+ salt were gradually added under constant stirring. Synthesis of the lighter Ln3+, i.e. La3+ through Eu3+, derivatives usually required additional HCl to reach the high Cl-/Ln3+ molar ratios, in some case >9, necessary to incorporate Cl- into the structures. In all cases, the final pH of the mixed solution was adjusted to ~0.6 with HCl. After several days, crystals of the final products appeared. The crystals were collected by filtration and dried in air. Typical yields were ~70%. Further attempts to replace Cl- by other anions, such as SO4 2-, PO4 3-, and Br- in the same structure were unsuccessful.

elements.content: The observation that Cl–/Ce3+ molar ratios lower than that required to synthesize [Ln­(H 4 NMP)­(H 2 O) 2 ]­Cl·2H 2 O usually led to a different crystalline phase prompted us to further investigate this. The Ce3+ derivative was selected as a representative material. The title compound was isolated by using the Ce3+ nitrate salt and H2SO4 to adjust the pH. Yield ∼70%. Elemental CHN composition (%) for Ce–H3NMP. Calcd: 7.09% C, 3.63% H, 2.76% N. Found: 6.76% C, 3.43% H, 2.38% N.

elements.content: Elemental analyses (C, H, N) were measured on a Perkin–Elmer 240 analyzer. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) data were recorded on an SDT-Q600 analyzer from TA Instruments. The temperature varied from RT to 900 °C, at a heating rate of 10 °C/min. Measurements were carried out on samples in open platinum crucibles under a flow of air. Thermogravimetric analysis-mass spectrometry coupled was performed with a thermobalance Mettler Toledo (model TGA-DSC1), using the same heating rate and temperature range, but under a N2 flow of 50 mL/min. The analyzer was connected to a mass spectrometer (MS) of Pfeiffer Vacuum (model ThermoStar GSD 320). Gases compositions were evaluated by using MS, and gases evolution profiles were also obtained as a function of temperature.
elements.clean_text:
Instrumentation

Elemental analyses (C, H, N) were measured on a Perkin-Elmer 240 analyzer. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) data were recorded on an SDT-Q600 analyzer from TA Instruments. The temperature varied from RT to 900 °C, at a heating rate of 10 °C/min. Measurements were carried out on samples in open platinum crucibles under a flow of air. Thermogravimetric analysis-mass spectrometry coupled was performed with a thermobalance Mettler Toledo (model TGA-DSC1), using the same heating rate and temperature range, but under a N2 flow of 50 mL/min. The analyzer was connected to a mass spectrometer (MS) of Pfeiffer Vacuum (model ThermoStar GSD 320). Gases compositions were evaluated by using MS, and gases evolution profiles were also obtained as a function of temperature.

elements.content: Diffuse reflectance UV–vis spectra were recorded using a Jasco V-670 spectrophotometer with a 60 mm integrating sphere. Photoluminescence spectra were recorded using the third harmonic of a Nd:Yag laser which excites the samples with radiation of λ = 355 nm. For the standard PL spectra setup, an optical fiber is utilized to transmit the fluorescence signal to a UV–visible (300–1000 nm) spectrometer (S2000, Ocean Optics Inc. (OOI)), and the acquired spectrum can be interpreted via OOI software. A background spectrum of an empty sample holder was recorded prior to the sample spectra, which showed no response to the laser excitation. The materials were also investigated to see if there was any emission in the IR region (1000–2000 nm), but no responses were observed. For the Eu–H4NMPCl derivative fluorescence emission measurements were carried out in an Edinburgh Instrument FLS920 fluorometer, using a 450 W Xe lamp as excitation source and a Starna 20-C support for solid samples. The excitation wavelength was 355 nm, and the spectrum was registered using 2 nm excitation and emission slits opening and a dwell time of 0.2 s.

elements.content: Single crystal X-ray diffraction data for La–H 4 NMPCl was collected on a SMART 1K CCD diffractometer at 150(2) K with Mo Kα (λ = 0.71073 Å). Single crystal X-ray diffraction data for Ho–H 4 NMPCl were collected on Bruker D8 Venture and on a Bruker X8 Proteum for Pr–H 4 NMPCl. The data were processed with APEX2 program and corrected for absorption using SADABS. The structures were solved by direct methods, which revealed the position of all non-hydrogen atoms. These atoms were refined on F2 by a full-matrix least-squares procedure using anisotropic displacement parameters. All hydrogen atoms were located in difference Fourier maps and included as fixed contributions riding on attached atoms with isotropic thermal displacement parameters 1.2 (−C-H) or 1.5 (−O-H) times those of the respective atom.
elements.clean_text:
Structural Determinations

Single crystal X-ray diffraction data for La-H  4  NMPCl was collected on a SMART 1K CCD diffractometer at 150(2) K with Mo Kα (λ = 0.71073 Å). Single crystal X-ray diffraction data for Ho-H  4  NMPCl were collected on Bruker D8 Venture and on a Bruker X8 Proteum for Pr-H  4  NMPCl. The data were processed with APEX2 program and corrected for absorption using SADABS. The structures were solved by direct methods, which revealed the position of all non-hydrogen atoms. These atoms were refined on F2 by a full-matrix least-squares procedure using anisotropic displacement parameters. All hydrogen atoms were located in difference Fourier maps and included as fixed contributions riding on attached atoms with isotropic thermal displacement parameters 1.2 (-C-H) or 1.5 (-O-H) times those of the respective atom.

elements.content: Laboratory X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) patterns for Ln-H 4 NMPCl (Ln = Sm, Eu, Gd, Tb, Dy) were collected on a PANanalytical X’Pert Pro diffractometer using a Bragg–Brentano reflection configuration with Ge(111) primary monochromator (Cu Kα1) and X’Celerator detector. For Ce–H 3 NMP data were collected using a Empyrean PANalytical diffractometer (Cu Kα1,2) equipped with an PIXcel 1D detector in a Bragg–Brentano configuration. All scans were collected under sample spinning within the range of 4°–90° (2θ) using a step size of 0.017 and a counting time between 300–500 s/step. Crystal structures were refined by the Rietveld method, using the GSAS package, and the structures of [La2(H3NMP)2(H2O)4]·4.5H2O (CCDC no. 1040381) and [La­(H4NMP)­(H2O)2]­Cl·2H2O were used as structural models for the Rietveld refinements of Ce–H 3 NMP and Ln-H 4 NMPCl (Ln = Sm, Eu, Gd, Tb, Dy), respectively. Soft constraints were established to maintain chemically reasonable geometries for the phosphonate and N groups. The following soft constrains were used: /PO3C tetrahedron/P–O [1.53(1) Å], P–C [1.80(1) Å], O···O [2.55(1) Å], O···C [2.73(1) Å], C–N [1.50(1) Å], C···C [2.46(1) Å], and P···N [2.77(1) Å]. The final weight factors for the soft constrain histograms ranged between 10 and 20. Preferred orientation effects were minimized for polycrystalline samples Ln-H 4 NMPCl (Ln = Sm, Eu, Gd, Tb, Dy) by dilution and blended of the sample with spherical particles of Cab-O-Sil M-5 (Fluka) and it was refined along the [010] using the March–Dollase correction. Crystallographic and structure refinement data are given in , and the final Rietveld plots for compounds Ce–H 3 NMP and Ln-H 4 NMPCl (Ln = Sm, Eu, Gd, Tb, and Dy) are given as (SI), Figures S1–S6. Crystal structures have been deposited at the CCDC, and the reference codes are also given in . Main bond distances are displayed in .

Thermodiffractometric studies at different relative humidity values were collected on a D8 ADVANCE (Bruker AXS) diffractometer equipped with a Johansson Ge(111) primary monochromator, which gives a strictly monochromatic Mo radiation (λ = 0.7093 Å), and an Anton Paar MHC-trans chamber. The X-ray tube was operating at 50 kV and 50 mA. The energy-dispersive linear detector LYNXEYE XE 500 μm, optimized for high energy radiation, was used with the maximum opening angle. Data were collected at the temperature range 25–120 °C, at low (10%) relative humidity (RH), and between 25 and 80 °C, at 95% RH using a heating rate of 1 °C/min. Samples, as thin pellets, were measured between 2 and 21° (2θ) with a step size of 0.017° and counting time of 192 s/step. Samples were hold at each temperature for 10 min, before recording any pattern, giving sufficient time for any transformation to take place.

elements.content: Impedance measurements were carried out on cylindrical pellets (diameter ∼5 mm and thickness ∼1 mm) obtained by pressing 40 mg of sample at 250 MPa, for 1 min. The pellets were pressed between porous C electrodes (Sigracet, GDL 10 BB, no Pt). The sample cells were placed inside a temperature- and humidity-controlled chamber (Espec SH-222) and connected to a HP4284A impedance analyzer. AC impedance data were collected over the frequency range from 20 Hz to 1 MHz with an applied voltage of 1 V. To equilibrate water content, pellets were first preheated (0.2 °C/min) from 25 to 80 °C at 10 °C intervals and RH 95%. A stabilization time of 1 h was allowed at each temperature. Impedance spectra were recorded on cooling using the same protocol and stabilization times of 1–2 h. Water condensation on sample was avoided by reducing first the relative humidity before decreasing temperature. All measurements were electronically controlled by the winDETA package of programs.

elements.content: All compounds with composition [Ln­(H4NMP)­(H2O)2]­Cl·2H2O (Ln = La, Pr, Sm, Eu, Gd, Tb, Dy and Ho) were obtained under soft conditions by crystallization at room temperature in contrast to other already reported layered and monodimensional lanthanide nitrilotris­(methylphosphonates). Chloride ions are incorporated into the crystal structure by using HCl to adjust the reaction pH. However, experiments conducted with Ce3+ ion using Cl–/Ce3+ molar ratios similar to those employed for other Ln-H 4 NMPCl systematically led to the 1D solid [Ce2(H3NMP)2(H2O)4]·4.5H2O, instead of the chlorinated compound. This compound is isostructural with the La derivative, previously obtained by hydrothermal and/or microwave-assisted procedures.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

All compounds with composition [Ln(H4NMP)(H2O)2]Cl⋅2H2O (Ln = La, Pr, Sm, Eu, Gd, Tb, Dy and Ho) were obtained under soft conditions by crystallization at room temperature in contrast to other already reported layered and monodimensional lanthanide nitrilotris(methylphosphonates). Chloride ions are incorporated into the crystal structure by using HCl to adjust the reaction pH. However, experiments conducted with Ce3+ ion using Cl-/Ce3+ molar ratios similar to those employed for other Ln-H  4  NMPCl systematically led to the 1D solid [Ce2(H3NMP)2(H2O)4]⋅4.5H2O, instead of the chlorinated compound. This compound is isostructural with the La derivative, previously obtained by hydrothermal and/or microwave-assisted procedures.

elements.content: It is interesting to note that the very low pH (0.6) used for the synthesis is necessary for successful isolation of crystalline products. Lower pH values lead to no precipitation, and higher pH values result in rapid product precipitation and, consequently, low-crystallinity compounds. This is not unusual for lanthanide-containing phosphonate materials, and has been noted before by us for lanthanide-HPAA materials (HPAA = hydroxyphosphonoacetic acid). We attempted to further extend the series [LnH4NMP)­(H2O)2]­Cl·2H2O beyond the Ho3+ derivative but, at present, we have only isolated another, as of yet, unidentified phase corresponding to the Er3+ derivative.

elements.content: We have also studied the morphological features of the crystalline products [Ln­(H4NMP)­(H2O)2]­Cl·2H2O and [Ce2(H3NMP)2(H2O)4]·4.5H2O by SEM, see . It appears that most of them are elongated rectangular plates, except the Ce compound, whose morphology resembles very thin needles. These rectangular plates show a tendency to aggregate, thus creating globular (see the La case) or flower-like (see the Gd or Sm cases) morphologies. The Ce compound seems to form very large, continuous aggregates (>200 μm).

elements.content: The synthesized [Ln­(H4NMP)­(H2O)2]­Cl·2H2O compounds (Ln = La, Pr, Sm, Eu, Gd, Tb, Dy and Ho) are isostructural and crystallize in the space group Cc. Relevant structural details will be discussed for the La3+ derivative, as a representative compound of the series. The asymmetric part of the unit cell consist of one La3+ ion, two coordinated water molecules, one H4NMP2– anionic ligand, two noncoordinated water molecules and one noncoordinated chloride ion (a). The octa-coordinated environment of La3+ is composed by six oxygen atoms from three different ligands and two oxygens from each bound water. It must be noted that the three crystallographically independent phosphonate groups are monodeprotonated, and the nitrogen atom of the ligand is protonated, thus rendering H4NMP2– a zwitterion. This is commonly encountered in other aminophosphonate-type compounds. Two of the three phosphonate groups act as both chelating and bridging linkers, while the third phosphonate group acts solely as a bridging moiety (b).
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structures

The synthesized [Ln(H4NMP)(H2O)2]Cl⋅2H2O compounds (Ln = La, Pr, Sm, Eu, Gd, Tb, Dy and Ho) are isostructural and crystallize in the space group Cc. Relevant structural details will be discussed for the La3+ derivative, as a representative compound of the series. The asymmetric part of the unit cell consist of one La3+ ion, two coordinated water molecules, one H4NMP2- anionic ligand, two noncoordinated water molecules and one noncoordinated chloride ion (a). The octa-coordinated environment of La3+ is composed by six oxygen atoms from three different ligands and two oxygens from each bound water. It must be noted that the three crystallographically independent phosphonate groups are monodeprotonated, and the nitrogen atom of the ligand is protonated, thus rendering H4NMP2- a zwitterion. This is commonly encountered in other aminophosphonate-type compounds. Two of the three phosphonate groups act as both chelating and bridging linkers, while the third phosphonate group acts solely as a bridging moiety (b).

elements.content: The layers are built up from isolated LnO8 polyhedra and bridge chelating NMP2– ligands. This connectivity creates infinite chains of interconnected LnO8 polyhedra (a), instead of forming edge-sharing polyhedra chains typical of other 1D and 2D structures reported elsewhere. The positively charged layers are held together through charge-compensating chloride ions located in the interlayer region in addition to lattice water (b).

elements.content: Each chloride ion in the interlayer region is H-bonded to two free P–OH groups from adjacent layers (O12 and O15) and three coordinated water molecules (), two of them belonging to the same layer (O6, O14) and the third (O14) from an adjacent layer. Thus, this structure represents an unusual class of layered phosphonate with positively charged layers. Noncoordinated water molecules (O1 and O2) participate in linear H-bond pathways by linking coordinated waters (O6 and O14) and free P–OH groups (O12, O15 and O24) along the a-axis. Both coordinated water molecules of the same LnO8 polyhedron are linked by H-bonds and contribute to the H-bond network.

elements.content: The 1D coordination polymer, [Ce2(H3NMP)2(H2O)4]·4.5H2O, isostructural with the La3+ derivative reported elsewhere, was obtained by simple crystallization at room temperature without the necessity of using microwave irradiation or hydrothermal synthesis. In this solid, chains formed by edge sharing LnO9 polyhedra are connected through the H3NMP3– ligands along the a axis and interact with each other through noncoordinated water molecules by H-bonds. Both coordinated and noncoordinated waters also assist the creation of H-bond pathways through interactions with the phosphonate groups (). The metal ion presents a distorted tricapped trigonal coordination environment formed by two water molecules and seven oxygen atoms originating from neighboring phosphonate groups.

In this solid, chains formed by edge sharing LnO9 polyhedra are connected through the H3NMP3- ligands along the a axis and interact with each other through noncoordinated water molecules by H-bonds. Both coordinated and noncoordinated waters also assist the creation of H-bond pathways through interactions with the phosphonate groups (). The metal ion presents a distorted tricapped trigonal coordination environment formed by two water molecules and seven oxygen atoms originating from neighboring phosphonate groups.

elements.content: On the other hand, the two-dimensional architecture reported for Pr–H3NMP·1.5H2O is characterized by a LnO8 octa-coordination environment, with the ligand acting simultaneously as singly unidentate, chelating bidentate, and chelating tridentate. Such high connectivity prevents inclusion of water molecules in the first coordination sphere of the lanthanide ion, which, in this case, is exclusively coordinated by phosphonate oxygens. Hence the different modes of metal–ligand coordination are mostly responsible for the structural variability observed in the system Ln3+/ H x NMP.

elements.content: Thermogravimetric analyses for three representative [Ln­(H4NMP)­(H2O)2]­Cl·2H2O samples (Ln = Sm, Gd, and Dy) are displayed in . The TGA curves show a weight loss in four steps. The first weight loss stage, up to ∼120 °C, corresponds to the loss of two lattice plus one coordinated water molecules (observed ∼9.5%, calculated 9.6%). The second stage, up to 180 °C, is characterized by a weight loss of ∼3.0% that corresponds to removal of the remaining bound water (calculated 3.2%). The third weight loss stage (∼6.0%), taking place in the range 180–400 °C, may be attributed to removal of the majority of chloride ions as HCl (calculated 7.4%) according to the TA-MS coupling results (). Thermal decomposition of the ligand occurs between 400 and 650 °C (∼8.0%), slightly overlapping with the HCl removal. For all Ln-H 4 NMPCl samples, total weight losses were in the range 25.6–27.6%. Thermal behavior of Ce–H 3 NMP agrees with that reported for lanthanum derivative, i.e., complete dehydration occurs around 150 °C ().
elements.clean_text:
Thermal Analyses

Thermogravimetric analyses for three representative [Ln(H4NMP)(H2O)2]Cl⋅2H2O samples (Ln = Sm, Gd, and Dy) are displayed in . The TGA curves show a weight loss in four steps. The first weight loss stage, up to ~120 °C, corresponds to the loss of two lattice plus one coordinated water molecules (observed ~9.5%, calculated 9.6%). The second stage, up to 180 °C, is characterized by a weight loss of ~3.0% that corresponds to removal of the remaining bound water (calculated 3.2%). The third weight loss stage (~6.0%), taking place in the range 180-400 °C, may be attributed to removal of the majority of chloride ions as HCl (calculated 7.4%) according to the TA-MS coupling results (). Thermal decomposition of the ligand occurs between 400 and 650 °C (~8.0%), slightly overlapping with the HCl removal. For all Ln-H  4  NMPCl samples, total weight losses were in the range 25.6-27.6%. Thermal behavior of Ce-H  3  NMP agrees with that reported for lanthanum derivative, i.e., complete dehydration occurs around 150 °C ().

elements.content: In order to evaluate possible structural changes upon heating, thermodiffraction studies () coupled with Rietveld refinements were carried out for sample Sm–H 4 NMPCl, exposed to heating and cooling cycles in the range 25 to 120 °C at RH 10%. At low relative humidity a slight increase of the cell volume is observed up to 80 °C after which the partial loss of water causes a progressive decrease of the a and b unit cell parameters (), at least up to 120 °C. These structural changes, reversible on cooling, are attributed to a variation from 8-fold to 7-fold coordination environment of lanthanide centers as confirmed by Rietveld refinement for sample heated at 120 °C (). Moreover, sample heating under air at 170 °C revealed that the structure rehydrated reversibly at room temperature (not shown).
elements.clean_text:
Structural Stability of Ln-H  4  NMPCl 

In order to evaluate possible structural changes upon heating, thermodiffraction studies () coupled with Rietveld refinements were carried out for sample Sm-H  4  NMPCl, exposed to heating and cooling cycles in the range 25 to 120 °C at RH 10%. At low relative humidity a slight increase of the cell volume is observed up to 80 °C after which the partial loss of water causes a progressive decrease of the a and b unit cell parameters (), at least up to 120 °C. These structural changes, reversible on cooling, are attributed to a variation from 8-fold to 7-fold coordination environment of lanthanide centers as confirmed by Rietveld refinement for sample heated at 120 °C (). Moreover, sample heating under air at 170 °C revealed that the structure rehydrated reversibly at room temperature (not shown).

elements.content: The behavior of samples Ln-H 4 NMPCl upon exposure at high RH (95%) and 80 °C is not straightforward (). La- and Pr–H 4 NMPCl compounds evolve to the 1D phase previously described, with lanthanum derivative being completely converted to this phase, as supported by Le Bail fit (). In addition, the SEM/EDS analysis confirms removal of chloride ions from the structure. In such high humidity conditions, a structural rearrangement results by deprotonation of a phosphonate group and a concomitant change in the connectivity of the phosphonate groups, from a configuration of three equivalent bridging groups to another one in which bridge-chelating, bridge and singly unidentate coordination modes coexist. In absence of more precise structural data to elucidate the mechanism, it is thought that the chloride ions become increasingly mobile on changing metal/ligand connectivity and eventually are removed as HClaq according to . This arrangement causes breaking of the layer and a change in coordination from LnO8 to LnO9. 2 [ Ln ( H 4 NMP ) ( H 2 O ) 2 ] Cl · 2 H 2 O + x H 2 O → [ Ln 2 ( H 3 NMP ) 2 ( H 2 O ) 4 ] · 4.5 H 2 O + 2 HCl aq

elements.content: Sm-, Eu- and Gd–H 4 NMPCl derivatives practically maintained their structural integrity at 95% RH and 80 °C provided that the treatment was ≤30 h, although XRD patterns for Sm- and Gd- showed an additional small and broad peak at low angle corresponding to an unidentified phase (). Moreover, at longer times (120 h), the Gd sample completely transformed to this unidentified phase, which was demonstrated by SEM/EDS analysis (not shown) to be a chloride-free compound. Ho–H 4 NMPCl also evolved to the same chloride-free unidentified phase. Elemental and thermal analysis of this compound match well with the composition Ho­[HN­(CH2PO3) (CH2PO3H)2]·1.5H2O (Calcd: 7.05% C, 2.16% H, 2.72% N. Found: 7.09% C, 2.44% H, 2.78% N; TGA-weight loss at 200 °C: Calc: 5.30%; Found: 5.86%). elements.content: The variable H-bonding arrangement may be anticipated to confer distinct proton conductivities in solids as revealed for other metal phosphonates. Thus, a comparative impedance spectroscopic study was undertaken, aimed to establishing structure-proton conductivity correlations. Samples were equilibrated at each temperature to ensure stable conductivity values. For this study, two kinds of materials, Gd–H 4 NMPCl and the chloride-free Ln derivatives (La, Ce, Gd, and Ho), were selected. Postimpedance thermogravimetric analyses were conducted in order to check possible variations in the hydration state of samples during measurements. No changes were observed in all cases [see (Ce–H 3 NMP) and (Gd–H 4 NMPCl) as examples].
elements.clean_text:
Proton Conductivity Studies

The variable H-bonding arrangement may be anticipated to confer distinct proton conductivities in solids as revealed for other metal phosphonates. Thus, a comparative impedance spectroscopic study was undertaken, aimed to establishing structure-proton conductivity correlations. Samples were equilibrated at each temperature to ensure stable conductivity values. For this study, two kinds of materials, Gd-H  4  NMPCl and the chloride-free Ln derivatives (La, Ce, Gd, and Ho), were selected. Postimpedance thermogravimetric analyses were conducted in order to check possible variations in the hydration state of samples during measurements. No changes were observed in all cases [see  (Ce-H  3  NMP) and  (Gd-H  4  NMPCl) as examples].

elements.content: Nyquist plots for samples equilibrated at 25 and 70 °C (95% RH) are shown in for representative compounds. At high temperature, impedance plots show similar features with spikes inclined to the Z′ axis by ∼70° with associated capacitances of ∼10 μF, indicating a partial blocking electrode response that allows limited diffusion and points to that the conducting species are H+ ions. At lower temperatures, i.e., 25 °C, broad arcs are observed at high frequencies with capacitances values of ∼10 pF due to the bulk response. Total pellet resistances (R T) values were obtained from the interception of the spike and/or the arc (low frequency end) on the Z′ axis.

elements.content: The proton conductivity for the chloride-free compounds ranges between 2 × 10–3 and 8 × 10–5 S·cm–1, at 80 °C and 95% RH, for La and Ce derivatives. Both transformed and as synthesized La–H3NMP compounds exhibited similar proton conductivities despite the fact that these samples were obtained by different methods, indicating that this property is characteristic of the coordination network rather than being an extrinsic feature. It is also remarkable that the activation energies (0.2–0.3 eV) of these compounds were significantly lower than that exhibited by the chlorinated 2D material, Gd–H 4 NMPCl, being typical of a Grotthuss proton transfer mechanism (<0.5 eV).

elements.content: Absorption and luminescence spectra were recorded for selected Ln-H 4 NMPCl compounds. In all of them, the observed transitions are attributed solely to f–f transitions of the lanthanide ions present, as the H4NMP2– organic group has no measurable absorption or luminescence properties. The electronic spectra for the studied samples show strong absorption bands below ∼250 nm assumed to arise from charge transfer transitions, i.e., 4f n → 4f n‑15d1, which are “allowed” under all the selection rules, and therefore, they have been excluded from tables of band assignments. shows the UV–vis absorption and photoluminescence spectra, under excitation at 355 nm, for Pr–H 4 NMPCl with the corresponding band assignments (see also ). Its absorption spectrum shows several intense peaks in the visible and NIR regions, with the spin-allowed ΔS = 0 transitions being much more intense than those which are spin-forbidden. Excitation of the sample with light of wavelength 355 nm gives rise to three peaks in the visible region corresponding to the 3P0 →3HJ (J = 4–6), the most intense of which is the middle one of the three, namely 3P0 →3H5.
elements.clean_text:
UV-vis and Photoluminescence (PL) Spectra of [Ln(H4NMP)(H2O)2]Cl⋅2H2O Compounds [Ln3+ = Pr, Sm, Eu, Gd, Tb, Dy, and Ho]

Absorption and luminescence spectra were recorded for selected Ln-H  4  NMPCl compounds. In all of them, the observed transitions are attributed solely to f-f transitions of the lanthanide ions present, as the H4NMP2- organic group has no measurable absorption or luminescence properties. The electronic spectra for the studied samples show strong absorption bands below ~250 nm assumed to arise from charge transfer transitions, i.e., 4f n  → 4f n-15d1, which are "allowed" under all the selection rules, and therefore, they have been excluded from tables of band assignments.  shows the UV-vis absorption and photoluminescence spectra, under excitation at 355 nm, for Pr-H  4  NMPCl with the corresponding band assignments (see also ). Its absorption spectrum shows several intense peaks in the visible and NIR regions, with the spin-allowed ΔS = 0 transitions being much more intense than those which are spin-forbidden. Excitation of the sample with light of wavelength 355 nm gives rise to three peaks in the visible region corresponding to the 3P0 →3HJ (J = 4-6), the most intense of which is the middle one of the three, namely 3P0 →3H5.

elements.content: For Sm–H 4 NMPCl there are many states close to one another. In some cases, the width of the spectral bands precludes assignment to a specific transition, and encompasses a number of possibilities (). The most intense absorption transitions occur in the NIR region. These are the spin-allowed (ΔS = 0) 6H5/2 → 6FJ transitions, with the relative weakness of the other transitions arising from the fact that they are spin-forbidden. Irradiation of the sample with light of wavelength 355 nm, , leads to three observable lines corresponding to 4G5/2 → 6HJ (J = 9/2, 7/2, and 5/2). The first two of these are electric dipole transitions, while the latter, where ΔJ = 0, will have a significant magnetic dipole contribution.

elements.content: The emission properties of Eu3+ are well-known and the photoluminescent emission data for the Eu3+ derivative are consistent with those reported for other Eu-containing materials (see ). Emission for the 5D0 → 7F4 transition is not observed as it is obscured by the broad, intense harmonic associated with the excitation source. The quality of the data is limited and so should be treated with some caution. However, the data do not show crystal field splitting in this instance, which can indicate the low local symmetry around the Eu3+ ion.

elements.content: What is interesting for this material is the number of peaks observed in the emission spectrum. At an excitation wavelength of 355 nm, it feasible to populate the 5D0, 5D1, 5D2, and the 5L6 excited states. Emissions arising from 5D0 → 7F n (n = 0–4) are well-known and characterized and the 5D0 excited state is usually populated directly or by radiationless relaxation from higher energy excited states, hence reported emission spectra for Eu-containing materials are usually restricted to the 550–710 nm range. In the data recorded for this sample, however, there are two strong peaks associated with transitions from excited states other than 5D0; the 5L6 → 7F0 transition at 393 nm, and the 5D1 → 7F4 transition. Both are spin allowed (ΔS = 0) electric dipole transitions, and the former probably arises as a resonance from the excitation process.

elements.content: The f–f transitions in the UV–visible part of the spectrum of Tb–H 4 NMPCl are fairly weak (a). Interest lies in the breadth of the absorption envelope for this material, broadly covering all wavelengths measured below 400 nm, which means that it can be readily excited by a wide range of energies. Its photoluminescence spectrum (b and ) illuminated with light of wavelength 355 nm, displays the strong 5G4 → 7F J (J = 3–6) peaks commonly associated with the visible green response. The most intense peak is the 5G4 → 7F5 transition at 546 nm. Interestingly, the only observable “resonance” wavelength (where absorption and emission have the same wavelength) is at 489 nm. This implies that excitation to a higher energy excited state is followed by a nonradiative relaxation to the 5D4 state prior to radiative relaxation to the ground states.

elements.content: It is notable that a strong green emission is observed for material Tb–H 4 NMPCl despite the fact that Tb is the only lanthanide present. Excitation of an ion can migrate to a nearby neighbor if identical lanthanide ions are separated by only a few angstroms. The optical excitation is thus trapped at impurity or defect sites which ultimately gives rise to concentration quenching via the enhancement of nonradiative relaxation, or by 5D3 + 7F6 → 5D4 + 7F0 cross-relaxation and ultimately means that a visible luminescent response will have a much reduced intensity or may not be observed at all. As such it is usual to dope host materials with only 1–5 mol % of the trivalent lanthanide ion. In Tb–H 4 NMPCl, the Tb3+ ions are separated by distances of 5.588(2), 8.495(1), and 8.5503(2) Å, which means that a high luminescent efficiency can be achieved even when all cationic sites are occupied by Tb ions.

elements.content: The absorption spectrum of Dy–H 4 NMPCl, as shown in , shows the most intense peaks in the NIR region. The transitions observed in the UV–visible part of the spectrum are more resolved than in those reported in Dy-doped phosphate glasses allowing for relatively straightforward assignment (). The luminescence spectrum (λex = 355 nm), as shown in , is dominated by two strong peaks located at 483 and 573 nm corresponding to the 4F9/2 → 6H15/2 and 4F9/2 → 6H13/2 transitions. A weaker peak arising from the 4F9/2 →6H11/2 peak is observed at 651 nm.

elements.content: Herein, we reported a new family of isostructural cationic compounds having the general formula [Ln­(H4NMP)­(H2O)2]­Cl·2H2O (Ln = La, Pr, Sm, Eu, Gd, Tb, Dy, and Ho). The positively charged 2D layers are held together by interlayer chloride ions, which form extended H-bond networks with uncoordinated P–OH groups and with coordinated as well as lattice water molecules. In contrast to other 1D and 2D structures reported elsewhere, LnO8 polyhedra of the layer are isolated from each other, instead of forming edge-sharing polyhedra chains.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Herein, we reported a new family of isostructural cationic compounds having the general formula [Ln(H4NMP)(H2O)2]Cl⋅2H2O (Ln = La, Pr, Sm, Eu, Gd, Tb, Dy, and Ho). The positively charged 2D layers are held together by interlayer chloride ions, which form extended H-bond networks with uncoordinated P-OH groups and with coordinated as well as lattice water molecules. In contrast to other 1D and 2D structures reported elsewhere, LnO8 polyhedra of the layer are isolated from each other, instead of forming edge-sharing polyhedra chains.

elements.content: Reversible dehydration/hydration processes occur at low humidity (up to 170 °C), while the 2D structure tends to become unstable upon heating at 80 °C and 95% RH, without following a straightforward behavior according to the Ln3+ ionic radius. A mechanism of phase transformation 2D → 1D, for La and Pr derivatives, in which metal/ligand reorganization is accompanied by removal of HCl, is put forward. Conversely, Sm to Ho derivatives progressively transform into a distinct unidentified chloride-free semicrystalline phase.

elements.content: Impedance measurements reveal that the chloride-free compounds, except [Ce2(H3NMP)2(H2O)4]·4.5H2O, are better proton conducting solids than the chlorinated 2D Gd derivative. The latter exhibits a proton conductivity of 3 × 10–4 S·cm–1 (80 °C) at 95% RH, whereas those of 1D materials vary in the range10–4–10–3 S·cm–1, the highest values corresponding to the La derivative (σ ≈ 10–3 S·cm–1 at RH 95% and 80 °C). The 1D solids show a typical Grotthuss proton transfer mechanism with low E a values (0.2–0.3 eV).

cln_elements.content: The observation that Cl–/Ce3+ molar ratios lower than that required to synthesize [Ln­(H 4 NMP)­(H 2 O) 2 ]­Cl·2H 2 O usually led to a different crystalline phase prompted us to further investigate this. The Ce3+ derivative was selected as a representative material. The title compound was isolated by using the Ce3+ nitrate salt and H2SO4 to adjust the pH. Yield ∼70%. Elemental CHN composition (%) for Ce–H3NMP. Calcd: 7.09% C, 3.63% H, 2.76% N. Found: 6.76% C, 3.43% H, 2.38% N.

The Ce3+ derivative was selected as a representative material. The title compound was isolated by using the Ce3+ nitrate salt and H2SO4 to adjust the pH. Yield ~70%. Elemental CHN composition (%) for Ce-H3NMP. Calcd: 7.09% C, 3.63% H, 2.76% N. Found: 6.76% C, 3.43% H, 2.38% N.

cln_elements.content:
Thermogravimetric analyses for three representative [Ln­(H4NMP)­(H2O)2]­Cl·2H2O samples (Ln = Sm, Gd, and Dy) are displayed in . The TGA curves show a weight loss in four steps. The first weight loss stage, up to ∼120 °C, corresponds to the loss of two lattice plus one coordinated water molecules (observed ∼9.5%, calculated 9.6%). The second stage, up to 180 °C, is characterized by a weight loss of ∼3.0% that corresponds to removal of the remaining bound water (calculated 3.2%). The third weight loss stage (∼6.0%), taking place in the range 180–400 °C, may be attributed to removal of the majority of chloride ions as HCl (calculated 7.4%) according to the TA-MS coupling results (). Thermal decomposition of the ligand occurs between 400 and 650 °C (∼8.0%), slightly overlapping with the HCl removal. For all Ln-H 4 NMPCl samples, total weight losses were in the range 25.6–27.6%. Thermal behavior of Ce–H 3 NMP agrees with that reported for lanthanum derivative, i.e., complete dehydration occurs around 150 °C ().

The overall pellet conductivities, in a traditional Arrhenius plot, are given in . Gd–H 4 NMPCl showed a proton conductivity of 3 × 10–4 S·cm–1 (80 °C) similar to those found for polycrystalline heterometallic Co–Ca phosphonate [CoIIICaII(notpH2)­(H2O)2]­ClO4·nH2O [notpH6 = 1,4,7-triazacyclononane-1,4,7-triyl-tris­(methylenephosphonic acid).
